content:
Sure, here is the updated hierarchy with the added elements:

* Sentence:
	+ Clause (Independent or Dependent)
		- Subject
			* Predicate
				+ Verb Phrase (Main Verb, Auxiliary Verb)
					- Object
						* Complement
							+ Modifier (Adjective, Adverb)
								- Phrase (Noun, Verb, Adjective, Adverb, Prepositional, Gerund, Infinitive)
									* Word (Noun, Verb, Adjective, Adverb)
										+ Letter

It's worth noting that this hierarchy is a simplification of the complex structure of language and the subject, object, complement, and modifier can appear in different positions in a sentence depending on the context, and can be omitted or implied, and can be different types of phrases or clauses. Additionally, a sentence can contain more than one subject, object, complement or modifier, and they can also be nested within each other.
